Problem:
Consider a continuous time system where the output \\( z(t) \\) is defined by the equation \\( z(t) = \\int_{0}^{t} K(s)y(s) ds \\), with \\( K(s) \\) and \\( y(s) \\) representing kernel and input functions, respectively. We investigate the effect of an input transformation \\( y'(s) = y(s) + h(s) \\), where \\( h(s) \\) is another function, on the output over time.

If the transformation \\( y'(s) = y(s) + h(s) \\) is applied at t = 0 and the system evolves under the original equation without any further intervention, will the output \\( z(t) \\) at any time t be the same as if only \\( y(s) \\) was applied directly?
Explanation: The transformation by adding \\( h(s) \\) to \\( y(s) \\) changes the input function from the initial point, thereby altering the integral computation of \\( z(t) \\). This change in input modifies the output \\( z(t) \\) directly because the integral now includes the contribution from \\( h(s) \\).
